description: From Middle English *squalen (not recorded) and squelen (“to cry, scream, squall”), from Old Norse skvala (“to cry out”), probably ultimately imitative with influence from squeal and bawl.
Cognate with Swedish skvala (“to gush, pour down”), Norwegian skval (“sudden rush of water”). The noun is probably from the verb.

entries.meaning: (meteorology) A squall line, multicell line, or part of a squall line.
(often nautical) A sudden storm, as found in a squall line.

verbs.description: squall (third-person singular simple present squalls, present participle squalling, simple past and past participle squalled)

examples: Squalling like an infuriated cat, the shadow crashed down
